trigger: Everything feels too bright or loud
normalization: Heightened sensory sensitivity is a known psilocybin response. It's temporary.
action: Move to a dimmer, quieter space. If you can't move, close your eyes and cover your ears gently.

normalization: Anxiety during onset is common, especially with a new batch or higher dose. Your body is adjusting.
action: Place both hands on a cold surface. Press firmly. Focus on the temperature and pressure.
timeline: Acute anxiety usually peaks at 30-45 minutes and subsides by 90 minutes.

trigger: I can't tell if I'm feeling something
normalization: The threshold zone between sub-perceptual and perceptual is ambiguous by definition. That's the territory we're mapping.
action: Stop looking for effects. Do something you'd normally do. Check back in 30 minutes.
timeline: If nothing after 90 minutes, this dose was likely sub-threshold for you today.

trigger: I feel disconnected from my body
normalization: Dissociative feelings can occur, especially at higher thresholds. You're safe.
action: Press your feet into the floor. Wiggle your toes. Squeeze your hands into fists, then release.
timeline: Body reconnection usually happens within 15-30 minutes with grounding.

normalization: Increased thought speed is a common cognitive effect. It's not dangerous, but it can feel overwhelming.
action: Pick one thought. Say it out loud. Let the rest go for now.
timeline: Racing thoughts typically slow within 30-60 minutes.

normalization: Emotional openness is one of psilocybin's most well-documented effects. Tears are a release, not a problem.
action: Let it happen. You don't need to understand it right now. If you want, place a hand on your chest.
timeline: Emotional waves pass. They always do. Usually within 20-40 minutes.

normalization: Nausea is common with psilocybin, especially on an empty or full stomach. It's your gut, not your mind.
action: Sip room-temperature water. Ginger helps if available. Lie on your left side if you can.
timeline: Nausea typically passes within 30-45 minutes of onset.

normalization: Time dilation or compression is a common perceptual shift. Clocks still work even when time doesn't feel normal.
action: Set a timer for 10 minutes. When it goes off, you'll have proof that time is still passing normally.
timeline: Time perception normalizes as effects plateau, usually within 60-90 minutes.

trigger: I'm having difficulty with people around me
normalization: Social sensitivity increases with psilocybin. Other people's energy can feel louder.
action: It's okay to leave the room. You don't owe anyone an explanation. Find a quiet space.
timeline: Social sensitivity is dose-dependent. Lower thresholds = less impact.

trigger: I feel amazing and want to take more
normalization: This is important to hear right now: the urge to redose during a positive experience is common but almost always leads to overshooting.
action: Do not redose. Write down how you feel instead. This is data. Log the dose amount â€” this might be your sweet spot.
timeline: Log this dose. If it's consistently this good, you've found your sweet spot. Redosing would move you past it.

trigger: I think I took too much
normalization: If you're reading this, you're oriented enough to use a phone. That's a good sign. You're going to be fine.
action: Go to Settle Mode. Start with breathing. You don't have to do anything except wait. Effects will diminish.
timeline: Psilocybin effects peak at 60-90 minutes and diminish over 3-4 hours. You will come down.

trigger: I need to talk to someone
normalization: Wanting support is not weakness. It's wisdom.
action: Call your emergency contact. If you don't have one, Fireside Project provides free psychedelic peer support: 62-FIRESIDE (623-473-7433).
